stream_context.summary: Kaze reworks a frustrating sub-area in Course 2 (Divine Dino Domain), replacing an older leaf-boat/autoscroll-like segment with a more open platforming playground. He discusses late-project planning (remaining courses, themes for late-game levels), current blockers (water/step-function crash, long loads and level instability, outdated warps), and shares production/tooling details (Fast64, Git backups) plus small personal/team context (Zeina’s haircut mishap; Zeina animations still needed for Course 12).
stream_context.significance_reason: Contains concrete late-production status (~80% complete), confirms Course 12 nearly shippable pending Zeina assets, outlines remaining course themes (13/14/15) including a secret Course 14 area, and documents technical constraints (water crash due to step-function migration; decomp area-loading limitations causing RAM/load-time issues).

findings.summary: Kaze is redesigning a previously unfun Course 2 sub-area, removing an older leaf-boat/autoscroll-style segment and replacing it with a freer platforming playground (moving platforms, coins, vines, stairs) to improve flow and reduce frustration when falling into water.

He is intentionally prioritizing gameplay-first iteration: block out geometry with primitives to validate jump rhythms and routes, then later commit to UV mapping, cohesive materials, and final art direction for the area.
findings.quote: Right now we just want the platforming to be fun. And then we can think about the visuals.

findings.summary: Course 12 was finished mostly off-stream and is close to “shippable,” with remaining tasks largely dependent on Zeina’s animations plus some signs and other simple finishing touches.
Overall project status is “just above 80%,” with Kaze stating there are three courses left to make/finish.
Late-game course planning: Course 13 is planned as a suspenseful/mysterious ice castle (still needs a boss concept), Course 14 as a “space arcade,” and Course 15 remains undecided.
Kaze has already started Course 14 and completed a secret area he cannot show because Eiza requested it stay hidden (it’s tied to a “compact”).

A known high-severity issue: water gameplay can crash the game because water logic has not yet been updated to the new step function, while the old step functions are no longer fully supported in the codebase.
findings.quote: Water hasn't been updated to the new step function yet and the old step functions are not fully supported anymore, so being in water can just crash the game.

findings.summary: During work on Divine Dino Domain, Kaze observes abnormally long loading times and repeated instability/crashes, suggesting a level-specific bug/regression that needs investigation before polishing.

A warp regression exists due to reordered level flow: the submarine warp now sends the player to the wrong destination because the warp table/pathway is no longer up to date after changing level order.

Decomp-specific content-streaming limitation: all sub-areas are currently loaded “in one go.” The older binary-era tool (RoamManager) supported area-by-area loading, but it’s not usable in decomp, costing RAM. Implementing segmented loads would require linker-script work Kaze hasn’t learned yet.
findings.quote: There used to be a tool called RoamManager... But that is made for binary, so we can't use it with decomp.

findings.summary: Testing environment friction: Kaze strongly dislikes the Parallel emulator because of updates, slower workflow, controller problems, and ROM-specific issues that do not reproduce on real N64 hardware; he uses a GameCube controller and also mentions having a separate, unreleased emulator for debugging tools.
Pipeline detail: they use Fast64 (a Blender extension) to export F3D for the project’s N64 rendering pipeline.
findings.quote: We're using Fast64 for that... it is a Blender extension that exports F3D.

findings.summary: Kaze uses Git as his primary backup system for the project (including 3D models) because asset sizes are small enough; he is wary of OneDrive and inadvertently cloud-syncing all work.
He avoids offering Patreon bonuses for ROM-hack enhancements due to perceived legal risk with Nintendo, implying a deliberate strategy to minimize monetization vectors that could trigger enforcement.
findings.quote: I also don't give out any Patreon bonuses. Because that might get me in legal trouble with Nintendo.

findings.summary: Zeina accidentally created a visible bald line while cutting Kaze’s hair (clipper guard fell off), leading him to wear a beanie/hood and turning it into a humorous but real on-stream moment about embarrassment and public persona.

biobak.summary: Biobak is referenced in passing during Blender workflow discussion (Kaze mentions hating “Biobak snapping,” likely an in-joke or a particular snapping setup), but no direct design feedback from Biobak is captured in this transcript.

zeina.summary: Zeina still needs to deliver a few remaining animations for Course 12 to be fully ready; Kaze frames these as the main remaining dependency for that course’s completion.
Zeina cut Kaze’s hair and accidentally created a bald stripe when the clipper guard fell off; Kaze jokes about it extensively and uses it to explain why he’s wearing a hat/hood.

findings.summary: Kaze calls out AkiDev as the original author of Chain Chomp code, and notes he recently modified it substantially to support a second Chain Chomp in a different level—evidence of reusing/extending contributor code across courses.
Eiza asked Kaze not to show a Course 14 area on stream because it’s part of a “compact,” indicating coordination around controlled reveals/packaging of content.
ZeroVolt appears in chat during development, but no specific music-conversion or technical contribution is discussed in this segment.
Kaze mentions another N64-focused mod release is gated by SimpleFlips first playing it for a competition, suggesting influencer/competition timing influences release cadence.

key_stories.title: Replacing a bad autoscroll-like segment with a platforming playground (Course 2)
key_stories.summary: Kaze revisits an older Course 2 sub-area he now considers unfun and replaces the prior leaf-boat sequence with open platforming: stairs for recovery, above-water routes, vines, moving platforms, and a traversal goal toward a Yoshi statue. He repeatedly emphasizes blockout-first iteration before committing to art/UV work.
key_stories.challenge: The previous leaf-boat/autoscroll-style section felt bad to play and made falling into water overly punishing.
key_stories.process: He blocks out new geometry with primitives, tests jump lines, adds recovery stairs on both sides, experiments with vine placement and optional shortcuts, and plans to add a Yoshi statue setpiece plus a red coin objective.
key_stories.outcome: A functional new layout is taking shape, with final remaining beats called out (Yoshi God statue, red coin, visual cohesion/UV mapping).
key_stories.key_quote: Right now we just want the platforming to be fun. And then we can think about the visuals.

key_stories.title: Course 12 is effectively done, pending Zeina’s final animations
key_stories.summary: Kaze reports Course 12 was finished mostly off-stream and is close to shipping quality. Remaining work is described as a small set of finishing touches, primarily Zeina’s animations plus a few signs.
key_stories.challenge: Final polish is blocked by dependent assets (animations) and minor content dressing.
key_stories.process: Kaze completes the bulk of implementation off-stream and keeps a short list of remaining tasks to integrate once animations are delivered.
key_stories.outcome: Course 12 is described as ready to ship once the remaining assets are added.

key_stories.title: Water can crash the game due to step-function migration
key_stories.summary: Kaze avoids water because it can crash the game: water code is still on an older step function path that is no longer fully supported. The issue appears serious enough to affect moment-to-moment testing in this level rework.
key_stories.challenge: Engine migration/regression where old movement/step code paths are incompatible with the newer framework, causing crashes in water contexts.
key_stories.process: He mitigates by limiting water interactions during testing and flags it as a known bug to resolve.
key_stories.outcome: Issue remains unresolved in-stream; it is a clear technical debt item that could block stability/QA.
key_stories.key_quote: Being in water can just crash the game.

key_stories.title: Decomp prevents area-by-area loading (RoamManager vs linker scripts)
key_stories.summary: Kaze explains that in decomp, the game currently loads all areas for a level at once. The older binary tool RoamManager supported incremental area loading, but isn’t compatible with decomp, leading to RAM waste and potentially contributing to long load times.
key_stories.challenge: Loss of a convenient binary-era streaming tool in the decomp workflow, with RAM and loading-time consequences.
key_stories.process: Kaze identifies the theoretical fix (load areas one-by-one) but notes it requires linker-script expertise he hasn’t learned yet.
key_stories.outcome: Current approach remains monolithic loading; a future refactor is possible but skill/time constrained.
key_stories.key_quote: If you wanted to load the areas one by one, you need to learn a lot of linker script that I haven't learned yet.

key_stories.title: Secret Course 14 work kept off-stream at Eiza’s request
key_stories.summary: Kaze confirms he has already built a full area for Course 14 but won’t show it because Eiza asked to keep it hidden as part of a “compact.” This reveals coordination around controlled reveals and packaging of content late in development.
key_stories.challenge: Balancing community transparency with team requests and planned reveal strategy.
key_stories.process: Kaze develops the area “in secret” and withholds footage/details on stream.
key_stories.outcome: A portion of Course 14 exists but is intentionally undisclosed until the agreed moment.
